Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Generating Models for Systems Based on Their Response to Unmeasured Inputs
Award.AbstractNarration:
Automatic control permeates modern life--from the autonomous navigation of ground and air vehicles to the regulation of glucose levels in the bloodstream via an artificial pancreas; but the quality of controllers stems from an intricate understanding of the underlying processes they manipulate. System identification is the technique of building a mathematical model for a dynamic process by observing its reaction to different inputs. The identified model uncovers the fundamental interactions at play in the system, and helps inform the design of controllers. However, the inputs creating a system response are often uncertain, or unmeasured; such as the turbulent forces buffeting an aircraft during flight. This research will develop techniques for generating a model for a system when its response is observed, but the input causing this response is unknown. This research will be conducted at National Cheng Kung University in Tainan City, Taiwan, in collaboration with Dr. Jer-Nan Juang, a pioneer in the field of system identification.

The popular Eigensystem Realization Algorithm (ERA) will be extended to identify models for linear time-invariant systems where only output data is available. Specifically, the outcomes include: 1) the rigorous definition of the set of conditions a system must satisfy in the presence of input uncertainty in order to be identifiable; including the locations of sensors and/or actuators, and the relative modal content of the system and the input; 2) an augmentation of the ERA algorithm permitting the identification of plants and inputs, down to a constant scaling factor, from output-only data; and 3) a linear solution for the recovery of the transformation which maps the identified system into physical coordinates, allowing for the decoupling of system modes and input modes. This NSF EAPSI award is funded in collaboration with the Ministry of Science and Technology in Taiwan.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of my journey to Taiwan through the 2015 EAPSI program was to develop an output-only system identification algorithm, and equally, if not more importantly, to enjoy cultural exchange and collaborate with Taiwanese graduate students in the System Control Lab at National Cheng Kung University (NCKU), in Tainan. I worked under the leadership of Dr. Jer-Nan Juang, a pioneer in system identification theory.

System identification is a technique for recovering models for dynamical systems based on experimental data including system inputs and outputs. Sometimes, this experimental data lacks information about the cause of a system response, and only includes the system response itself. Recovering a system model in this case is often referred to as “blind” system identification, or output-only identification; because input information is missing. We approached this problem for linear systems, assuming that the unknown system inputs are multimodal, harmonic signals. An interesting property afforded by this assumption about the inputs is that the input signals themselves are the product of another linear dynamic process, which we can additionally identify. In this way, we can proceed in the identification process, unhindered by the fact that we don’t know explicitly what the input signal is. Thus, our task was to identify an augmented system, which contains information about the physical system we observe; but also the hidden, input system, which generates the unmeasured inputs that excite the physical system. We accomplished this with the Eigensystem Realization Algorithm (ERA); however, the next challenge was to partition the augmented model into the “physical” part, and the “input part,” because the identification algorithm inadvertently disguises this distinction. Most of our effort was spent addressing this problem of isolating properties of the physical system from the overall, augmented system. We sought to determine the transformation matrix which, upon operating on the augmented system matrix, clearly separates the physical and input components. For the idealized (and unrealistic) case where both the physical system and input system are known a priori, we found a unique expression for this transformation matrix. However, for the generalized case encountered in practice, where we do not assume any system knowledge, save for the most basic kinematical assumptions of mechanical systems, a set of nonlinear equations needed to be solved to yield the transformation matrix. We found these equations to yield two solutions; one solution properly isolates the physical system from the identification process, while the other solution mistakes the input system for the physical system. It is not yet clear if we can distinguish between these two cases, in practice.

In addition to allowing me to study this system identification problem under the mentorship of Dr. Jer-Nan Juang, this EAPSI fellowship gave me the opportunity to spend a summer working with, traveling with, working out with, and eating with my lab-mates from NCKU. I had the privilege to learn from, but also mentor my Taiwanese colleagues. The experience fostered collaboration which has continued beyond the duration of my summer stay. I experienced numerous facets of Taiwanese culture, including visiting night markets, riding scooters, hiking, river tracing, making tea, and many more. This experience provided by the EAPSI fellowship has enhanced my research skills, my professionalism, and also my global perspective.
